children.value: Before you create a custom schema directive,
Your schema can define custom directives that can then decorate

When Apollo Server loads your schema on startup, it can execute custom logic wherever it encounters a particular directive. For example, it can modify the resolver function for a decorated field (for the schema above, it could transform the
A directive definition looks like this:
The directive takes one optional argument (
The directive can decorate any number of
in the schema locations you list after the
The table below lists all available locations in a GraphQL schema. Your directive can support any combination of these locations.
The definition of a field within any defined type
The definition of a field argument
The definition of one value within an
The definition of a field within an
After you define your directive and its valid locations, you still need to define the logic that Apollo Server executes whenever it
To accomplish this, you create a subclass of

In your subclass, you override the
your directive can appear in. You can see each location's corresponding visitor method in
version 4. To use another version of the library, see

This subclass adds two fields to the executable schema's representation of a deprecated field or enum value: a boolean indicating that the item

To add this logic to Apollo Server, you pass the
When Apollo Server parses your schema SDL to create your executable schema, it automatically initializes a separate
it encounters. It then calls the appropriate visitor method for the current location.
subclass any name. It doesn't need to match the name of the directive it's used for (you can even use the same subclass for multiple directives).
Running directive logic on an executable schema
parsed your SDL string into an executable schema, you can still execute directive logic by calling the static method

A custom directive can transform a resolved GraphQL field's value
it's returned to the requesting client.
Suppose you want to convert certain
fields in your schema to uppercase before they're returned.
field with a new function. This new function first calls the
resolver, then transforms its result to uppercase (assuming it's a string) before returning it.

Fetching data from a REST API
Suppose you've defined an object type that corresponds to a
resource, and you want to avoid implementing resolver functions for every field:
There are many more issues to consider when implementing a real GraphQL wrapper over a REST endpoint (such as how to do caching or pagination), but this example demonstrates the basic structure.
Suppose you have a function called
that takes a string, a path identifying that string's role in your application, and a target locale for the translation.
Here's how you might make sure
GraphQL is great for internationalization, since a GraphQL server can access unlimited translation data, and clients can simply ask for the translations they need.

What makes this example tricky is that the
version of the directive needs to wrap all fields of the object, even though some of those fields may be individually wrapped by
level, and we would prefer not to rewrap resolvers if we can help it:
One drawback of this approach is that it does not guarantee fields will be wrapped if they are added to the schema after

is a made-up API that would need to be fleshed out. In other words, weâ€™ve glossed over some of the details that would be required for a production-ready implementation of this directive, though we hope the basic structure shown here inspires you to find clever solutions to the remaining problems.
Suppose you want to enforce a maximum length for a string-valued field:
Suppose your database uses incrementing IDs for each resource type, so IDs are not unique across all resource types. Hereâ€™s how you might synthesize a field called
that combines the object type with various field values to produce an ID thatâ€™s unique across your schema:
While the above examples should be sufficient to implement any
used in your schema, SDL syntax also supports declaring the names, argument types, default argument values, and permissible locations of any available directives:
is used without passing an explicit
to set a default access control for all
fields, and also on individual fields, to enforce field-specific
Enforcing the requirements of the declaration is something a
implementation could do itself, in theory, but the SDL syntax is easer to read and write, and provides value even if you're not using the
However, if you're implementing a reusable

for public consumption, you will probably not be the person writing the SDL syntax, so you may not have control over which directives the schema author decides to declare, and how. That's why a well-implemented, reusable
method receives not only the name of the directive but also the
object, it can modify and/or reuse previous declarations found in the schema, as an alternative to returning a totally new
object. Either way, if the visitor returns a non-null
, that declaration will be used to check arguments and permissible locations.
abstraction is specifically designed to enable transforming GraphQL schemas based on directives that appear in your SDL text.

While directive syntax can also appear in GraphQL queries sent from the client, implementing query directives would require runtime transformation of query documents. We have deliberately restricted this implementation to transformations that take place at server construction time.

We believe confining this logic to your schema is more sustainable than burdening your clients with it, though you can probably imagine a similar sort of abstraction for implementing query directives. If that possibility becomes a desire that becomes a need for you, let us know, and we may consider supporting query directives in a future version of these tools.
